bibl.title: Letter from Leatha Logan to Philip Showalter Hench, March 18, [1942]

div1.p: Logan informs Hench that he may keep the photographs she sent to him, but disputes Hench's statement concerning the number of experimental cases of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Leatha Logan to Philip Showalter Hench, March 18, [1942]
div1.p:
I intended you should keep all
of the pictures if you wished and you
are quite welcome to keep the one of
Dr. Carter should you return the others.

May I offer a criticism- In your
paper read at Washington Pa College
Oct- 1940 part say the Army Yellow
Fever Board “having produced seventeen
Cases of the disease” - etc experimental yellow fever" or words
to that effect.

You surely have in the clinical library
a copy of the Memorial to Walter Reed
published in 1911, I had that for a
month's study and in at least more
than one statement it said “Having
produced 22 cases of experimental yellow
fever “Camp Lazear was disbanded March first
1901”. As I copied the names there were
eight Americans by mosquito inoculation and
six Spaniards. Six Americans by Injection
of blood and 2 by blood serum.

Seven exposed to “fomites,” 4 of whom afterward
took either blood or blood serum tests. I am
sending this criticism. Thinking you may find it
helpful.
div1.closer:
Very Truly
Yours- L. Logan Ac
